articles.headline: Will the Pandemic Productivity Boom Last?
articles.snippet: Fewer workers are making more stuff. If it lasts, that’s big news for the economy of the 2020s.
articles.abstract: Fewer workers are making more stuff. If it lasts, that’s big news for the economy of the 2020s.
articles.lead_paragraph: For most of the last 15 years, the United States economy was mired in a period of low productivity growth. Who would have guessed that the pathway out of it might include a pandemic?

articles.headline: Biden Finds a Bipartisan Victory, but Democratic Unity May Prove More Elusive
articles.snippet: The Senate’s passage of a trillion-dollar infrastructure plan was vindication of President Biden’s commitment to bipartisanship, but for his larger agenda, he will need Democrats in lock step.
articles.abstract: The Senate’s passage of a trillion-dollar infrastructure plan was vindication of President Biden’s commitment to bipartisanship, but for his larger agenda, he will need Democrats in lock step.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate’s passage on Tuesday of a trillion-dollar infrastructure package may have been a vote of confidence for President Biden and his insistence that bipartisanship can still thrive, but there is a far harder task ahead for his agenda: keeping Democrats in lock step.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: Railing at Enemies and Pleading for Time: Inside Cuomo’s Final Days
articles.snippet: Behind the scenes, the governor vacillated between defiant and defeated, eventually accepting that his formidable political army had fallen away.
articles.abstract: Behind the scenes, the governor vacillated between defiant and defeated, eventually accepting that his formidable political army had fallen away.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was wearing everyone down.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer, Maggie Haberman, William K. Rashbaum and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: How Facebook Failed to Stem Racist Abuse of England’s Soccer Players
articles.snippet: For more than two years, soccer officials pushed the social network to limit the invective. As a new season begins, the hate continues.
articles.abstract: For more than two years, soccer officials pushed the social network to limit the invective. As a new season begins, the hate continues.
articles.lead_paragraph: In May 2019, Facebook asked the organizing bodies of English soccer to its London offices off Regent’s Park. On the agenda: what to do about the growing racist abuse on the social network against Black soccer players.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and Tariq Panja

articles.headline: Consumer Prices Keep Climbing as Fed and White House Await a Cool-Down
articles.snippet: A key inflation gauge again climbed 5.4 percent in July from a year earlier. Prices gains are expected to moderate — the question is by how much and how quickly.
articles.abstract: A key inflation gauge again climbed 5.4 percent in July from a year earlier. Prices gains are expected to moderate — the question is by how much and how quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumer prices rose at a rapid clip in July as the reopening of the economy kept inflation elevated at levels that are making officials at the Federal Reserve squirm while posing a political problem for the Biden White House.

articles.headline: Senate Passes $3.5 Trillion Budget Plan, Advancing Safety Net Expansion
articles.snippet: The blueprint, which would expand health care, provide free preschool and community college, and fund climate change programs, passed along party lines and faces an arduous path ahead.
articles.abstract: The blueprint, which would expand health care, provide free preschool and community college, and fund climate change programs, passed along party lines and faces an arduous path ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate took a major step on Wednesday toward enacting a vast expansion of the nation’s social safety net, approving a $3.5 trillion budget blueprint along party lines that would allow Democrats to tackle climate change and fund health care, child care, family leave and public education expansion.

articles.headline: Evicted, Despite a Federal Moratorium: ‘I Do Not Know What I Am Going to Do’
articles.snippet: Many local governments and courts were not sure how to apply the extension of the protections, and dockets in some places overflowed with evictions.
articles.abstract: Many local governments and courts were not sure how to apply the extension of the protections, and dockets in some places overflowed with evictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Inside Courtroom 8A of Las Vegas Justice Court last week, the benches were packed with renters and landlords battling over evictions that continued at a brisk pace despite a last minute, two-month extension of the federal protections meant to keep people in their homes.

articles.headline: One Number to Gauge Where the Economy Is Headed
articles.snippet: The yield on the 10-year Treasury note is often a reliable indicator of how Wall Street views the prospects of economic growth — especially when other data points send confusing signals.
articles.abstract: The yield on the 10-year Treasury note is often a reliable indicator of how Wall Street views the prospects of economic growth — especially when other data points send confusing signals.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are many ways to assess the prospects for economic growth — from the performance of the stock market, to the latest unemployment data, to inflation. But when none of those send a clear signal about the state of the economy, there’s one reading that investors, traders and economists often rely on: the yield on the 10-year Treasury note.

articles.headline: Greek Island Is New Epicenter of Europe’s Summer of Calamity
articles.snippet: Evia was ravaged by wildfires this week, adding to the list of places that have fallen victim to extreme weather events made worse by climate change and scorching temperatures.
articles.abstract: Evia was ravaged by wildfires this week, adding to the list of places that have fallen victim to extreme weather events made worse by climate change and scorching temperatures.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVIA, Greece — Amid twisted cages and scorched trees, Harilaos Tertipis stepped out of his ruined stables dragging the charred corpses of his sheep — burned, like so much else, in the wildfires that have raged across Greece.
